instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shorted PCH?
threads.message:
Have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had liquid damage and worked for a short bit after replacing everything affected by the spill but board died again during testing.

Checked power rails and found a short on <SIGNAL>PPV_SUS</SIGNAL>. I removed everything on that line excep tPCH but still have short. Does this confirm PCH needs to be replaced?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shorted PCH?
threads.message:
Have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had liquid damage and worked for a short bit after replacing everything affected by the spill but board died again during testing.

Checked power rails and found a short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>. I removed everything on that line except PCH but still have short. Does this confirm PCH needs to be replaced?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shorted PCH?
threads.message:
Is that short lower, or higher than 10 ohms?
Higher value points to PCH, or <CAPACITOR>C2438</CAPACITOR>.
If <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS_PCH_V5REFSUS</SIGNAL> shows lower value than <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> (when <CAPACITOR>C2438</CAPACITOR> removed), try heating PCH with good flux.
